verses.text: The LORD is my shepherd, I shall not be in want.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 23
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 23 This psalm is perhaps the best known example of a psalm of confidence (Introduction: Characteristics and Themes). It is a literary unity, with two governing metaphors expressing God’s care and goodness: the shepherd and the banquet table.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 23:1
rsbNotes.text: 23:1 shepherd. The image of God as shepherd is inexhaustibly rich. The shepherd stays with the flock (Is. 40:11; 63:9–12). His sheep are totally dependent upon him for food, water, and protection from wild animals. In the New Testament, Jesus is revealed as the shepherd of His people (John 10:11, 14), fulfilling the prophecy that God will come to shepherd His people (Ezek. 34:7–16, 23).

verses.text: He makes me lie down in green pastures, he leads me beside quiet waters,
he restores my soul. He guides me in paths of righteousness for his name's sake.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 23:2–3
rsbNotes.text: 23:2, 3 makes me lie down . . . leads me . . . restores . . . leads me. These verses extend the metaphor of the shepherd’s care for the sheep. The Lord lovingly cares for His people.

verses.text: Even though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for you are with me; your rod and your staff, they comfort me.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 23:4
rsbNotes.text:
23:4 valley of the shadow of death. See Job 10:21, 22.

rod . . . staff. The rod was used to fight wild animals and the staff to direct the flock.

verses.text: You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies. You anoint my head with oil; my cup overflows.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 23:5–6
rsbNotes.text: 23:5, 6 The Lord treats the psalmist as an honored guest.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 23:5
rsbNotes.text:
23:5 table. The image shifts to that of a banquet, a victory celebration.

anoint. Guests were anointed at feasts (Ps. 104:15; Luke 7:46).

verses.text: Surely goodness and love will follow me all the days of my life, and I will dwell in the house of the LORD forever.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 23:6
rsbNotes.text: 23:6 I shall dwell. Like the sheep with its shepherd, the psalmist quiets himself in God’s assurance of an eternal home with Him. See John 14:23; “God Is Love: Divine Goodness and Faithfulness” at Ps. 136:1.
